title: Massive Sunspot 2,00,000-Km-Long Threatens Earth With Gigantic Eruptions | Times Now
text: Sunspot AR3664 has recently garnered attention for its massive size, rivaling the legendary Carrington sunspot observed in 1859. NASA has released a composite image comparing Carrington's historic sketch with a current photograph of the sun, both scaled to size.How Big Is The Sunspot?AR3664 spans an impressive 200,000 kilometers from end to end, making it 15 times wider than Earth itself. Remarkably, this colossal sunspot can be observed with the naked eye through standard eclipse glasses, without any magnification.The Carrington sunspot gained prominence due to the intense solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs) it unleashed in August and September of 1859. These geomagnetic storms were so severe that they caused telegraph offices to catch fire and produced auroras visible from Cuba to Hawaii. This event, known as the "Carrington Event," has become a focal point in space weather discussions, with recent speculation about the potential impact of a similar event on modern technology.Studies suggest that Carrington-class storms occur approximately every 40 to 60 years, indicating that we are overdue for such an event. While the current CMEs approaching Earth are not expected to reach the magnitude of the 1859 event, the massive sunspot AR3664 continues to release CMEs toward our planet.Should We Worry?NOAA forecasts indicate that at least three storm clouds are currently heading towards Earth. The first CME is projected to reach our planet late on May 10th, followed by additional CMEs on May 11th and possibly 12th. These events could trigger minor to strong geomagnetic storms, potentially leading to auroras visible at mid-latitudes in Europe and the USA.These celestial displays offer a breathtaking sight but also underscore the potential risks posed by solar storms to our technology-dependent society. As AR3664 remains active, scientists and space weather experts are closely monitoring its behavior to assess any potential impacts.
